intro: Cheirolophus canariensis var. subexpinnata, commonly known as the Canary Island bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Canary Islands. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or coastal environments, showing a preference for well-drained soils. It has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces showy blooms during the spring and summer months. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it is considered rare in the wild.
